{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3224331,"name":"Espino","username":"HUGODANIEL09","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/74df32/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-08-10T20:05:00.410Z","cooked":"

Hello, I hope you are okay.

My has been trying to do the thread wheel for the Swerve X module but it looks loose. We made our jig with the drawing of WCP for the updated wheel, but we don´t know what it is the cause because it is a big error. I hope you can help us with this.

WhatsApp Image 2023-08-10 at 1.33.51 PM1474×1600 148 KB

Looks like there’s a new and old version for the wheels. https://docs.wcproducts.com/wcp-swervex/assembly-instructions/wheel-tread-cutting

The new template is slightly smaller. Which template did you use?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-08-10T21:07:25.872Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":319,"readers_count":318,"score":63.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":439698,"topic_slug":"swerve-x-thread-help","display_username":"Jon K.","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":25951,"username":"Technologyman00","name":"Technologyman00","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/technologyman00/{size}/178178_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1038,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-x-thread-help/439698/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3224349,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-10T21:23:07.331Z","cooked":"

You’ve really got to watch that the tread sits down inside the wheel edges (like the green section). If it rides up on top (like the red section) then it becomes very difficult to line up the holes. You may need to sand some of the edges of your tread to insure it fits correctly.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-08-10T21:23:07.331Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":322,"readers_count":321,"score":64.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":439698,"topic_slug":"swerve-x-thread-help","display_username":"John Hascall (he)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Opinions expressed are mine only"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-x-thread-help/439698/6","custom_user_title":"Opinions expressed are mine only","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3224352,"name":"2582","username":"chadr03","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadr03/{size}/195529_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-10T21:34:46.716Z","cooked":"

We used the provided measurements with good success this year, but we used 3 ply black tread. If I were to guess that is likely your problem. I have heard teams in the past have to modify their thread jigs when changing tread types because of how they wrap.

I would also verify that your Jig is actually the size you intended. Measure it and compare it to the drawing. We have accidently scaled parts in the past just a little bit and that can throw things off.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-08-10T21:34:46.716Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":306,"readers_count":305,"score":66.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":439698,"topic_slug":"swerve-x-thread-help","display_username":"2582","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13827,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-x-thread-help/439698/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3224555,"name":"","username":"bianca","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bianca/{size}/221825_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-11T23:36:34.486Z","cooked":"

I had this same problem, eventually gave up and punched the holes one by one with the tread on the wheel. And drilled the tread on the wheel and then riveted (Not recommended for re-use, though).

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-08-11T23:36:34.486Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":250,"readers_count":249,"score":65.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":439698,"topic_slug":"swerve-x-thread-help","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52512,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"live kwaq love ♡ 2423 & 777 alum"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-x-thread-help/439698/8","custom_user_title":"live kwaq love ♡ 2423 & 777 alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3225782,"name":"Liz","username":"Liz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/liz/{size}/215465_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-21T05:12:06.519Z","cooked":"

Hi there!!!

We were actually having the opposite issue last week, where our tread was just slightly too small for the wheels, despite following the exact measurements on the website. (and even eventually giving ourselves a bit of leeway.)

We ended up quickly coming up with CAD for a template of our own measurements, and fabricating that as to stick to our own measurements. That’s just one idea of a possible solution.

Hope this helps!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-08-21T05:12:06.519Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":172,"readers_count":171,"score":39.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":439698,"topic_slug":"swerve-x-thread-help","display_username":"Liz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60158,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-x-thread-help/439698/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3225812,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-21T13:44:41.488Z","cooked":"
Liz:

e were actually having the opposite issue last week, where our tread was just slightly too small for the wheels, despite following the exact measurements on the website. (and even eventually giving ourselves a bit of leeway.)

We ended up quickly coming up with CAD for a template of our own measurements, and fabricating that as to stick to our own measurements. That’s just one idea of a possible solution.

Hope this helps!

I have often considered putting short slots in the wheels instead of tapping bolt holes, then using pointed bolts with locknuts to lock the tread in place. This would allow for drilling the holes in the tread while it is on the wheel (you wouldn’t hurt the threads in the wheel since they don’t exist), and the slot gives you some leeway when you the tread doesn’t sit flat. Finally, the bolt+nut is reusable and you don’t chance screwing up your aluminum threads in the wheel when you are trying to stretch the tread just that little extra bit to get it on.

The pointed bolts will screw into even a very small hole you’ve drilled in the tread, so there is no messing around with trying to make the hole big enough to get a normal bolt into it.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-08-21T13:46:02.849Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":140,"readers_count":139,"score":58.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":439698,"topic_slug":"swerve-x-thread-help","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-x-thread-help/439698/10","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3226721,"name":"Jonathan Fletcher","username":"Jdfletch","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/96bed5/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-08-24T05:09:33.635Z","cooked":"

I posted a 3d print of the jig we made last season that worked well. Also lets you cut the tread to length and drill in one operation. The dimensions are custom, as others have mentioned here. They are a bit “tight”, and I’m talking a few thou in each dimension, and that yielded the best tight tread for us, and it was definitely trial and error to figure them out. This is sized for the 1.5" black neoprene roughtop from Thrifty Bot.

SwerveX Drill Jig

IMG_03651920×1440 211 KB

Obviously, this results in a plastic jig. They seem to last for about 20 ft of tread, and we print new as necessary. This will print on an Ender 3 sized bed, at a 45 degree angle. The model is oriented straight up so you’ll have to flip it upside down and turn it in your slicer.

Best of luck in 2023/2024 from the 3171 Hurricanes!
